tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

Possible meanings are 1) "song people sang while going up to Jerusalem for a celebration" or 2) "song people sang while going up the steps into the temple" or 3) "song whose words are like steps." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:120:001|120:1]]

tn.ref: The plowers plowed on my back
tn.text: The cuts from a whipping are spoken of as the plow of a plowman. A farmer plowed deep lines into a field. AT: "My enemies have cut me deeply on my back" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a continuation of the plowing metaphor. The "furrow" is the line the farmer plowed. AT: "they made their cuts long" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he has cut the ropes of the wicked
tn.text: Israel is spoken of as being bound by evil people. AT: "he has freed us from our enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: May they all be put to shame and turned back
tn.text: Yahweh is not explicitly mentioned as the one who does these things. This can be stated in active form. AT: "May Yahweh shame them and defeat them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The psalmist speaks of his enemies dying and being few in number. They are compare to the little bit of grass that grows on the roof of a house and withers and is not enough to cut or bundle. AT: "May they die and may there be so few of them that they would be like the grass ... sheaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: the blessing of Yahweh be on you
